ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

RESETTLEMENT OF FARMERS LIVING
IN CHOA CHU KANG ROAD


    1. Mr Chio Cheng Thun asked the Prime Minister whether he is aware that the farmers living in the area between 14½ milestone and 17 milestone, Choa Chu Kang Road, have been given notice by the Government to vacate the land they occupy; for what purpose is the vacated land intended to be used; where will these farmers be resettled; and what compensation, if any, will they get from the Government.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Inche Yaacob bin Mohamed Al-Haj) (for the Prime Minister) (In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Choa Chu Kang is presumably referring to the land situated between 14¾ and 15¼ mile, Choa Chu Kang Road, which forms part of some 1,500 acres of State land set aside for use as a public burial ground and burial reserve. Fifteen families - of whom only six are families of farmers - on this site were served notices to quit in October. They were warned as early as

Column: 554

May this year that they would be required to vacate the land.

    The land is urgently required, as all available burial plots in Bidadari are expected to be taken up by the middle of next year.

    The farmers have been offered land in the resettlement areas at 19½ mile Lim Chu Kang Road and 17½ mile Lim Chu Kang Road. Both these areas are well suited for cultivation.

    The compensation which will be awarded to these farmers will vary according to the size and construction of the houses which they now occupy. The total amount which will be paid to them has been assessed at approximately $22,000.

    Mr Chio Cheng Thun (Choa Chu Kang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Parliamentary Secretary did not give his answer in detail ---

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Mr Speaker, Sir, the hon. Member should not make any comment on the answer. All he can do is to ask further questions.

    Mr Speaker: The Member for Choa Chu Kang cannot make comments on the answer or lead to a debate. What he can do is to ask a supplementary question to elucidate any information on which he is not clear.

    Mr Chio Cheng Thun(In Mandarin): I would like to ask, to what use will the vacated land be put?

    Mr Speaker: That answer has been given. It is in the main question: "for what purpose is the vacated land intended to be used;". And I believe that question has been answered. We will proceed to Question No. 2 - Mr Ong Lian Teng.

VALUE OF TRADE WITH INDONESIA


    3. Mr Chio Cheng Thun asked the Minister for Finance what was the total value of trade of Singapore with Indonesia from 1st January, 1963, to 15th September, 1963; and what was the total value of trade of Singapore with Indonesia from 16th September, 1963, to 30th November, 1963.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, the question asked for details of trade between Singapore and Indonesia before confrontation and after confrontation. The 1963 classified trade statistics of Singapore are only available up to the month of June. I am therefore unable to provide the hon. Member with the details he sought. It is not my intention to publish in future trade statistics, any details whatsoever in respect of trade between Singapore and Indonesia after the 15th September this year. Information of this kind will be of the utmost value to the Indonesian Government in carrying out its policy of economic confrontation in the hope of bringing Malaysia down to its knees. In the economic war which is now being waged between the two countries, this kind of information constitutes valuable economic intelligence. The question of the

Column: 556

hon. Member is another example of how the Barisan Sosialis are attempting to give aid to the enemy. This time they want us to provide them with ---

    Mr Koo Young (Thomson)(In Mandarin): Point of order.

    Mr Speaker: What is the point of order?

    Mr Koo Young(In Mandarin): The Minister did not give us the figures we wanted. On the other hand, he was accusing the Barisan Sosialis of abetting enemies. Was he in order?

    Mr Speaker: The Minister was in order. A question has been asked, and the Minister is free to answer it.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: I have to explain not only why it is not in the public interest to give this information even if this information were available, I was going to point out that this is just another way in which the Barisan Sosialis are attempting to give aid to the enemy. This time they want us to provide them with valuable economic intelligence. I have not the slightest intention of obliging either the Barisan Sosialis or their Indonesian masters.

PIONEER INDUSTRIES IN JURONG AND RED HILL
(Number of persons newly employed)


    4. Mr Chio Cheng Thun asked the Minister for Finance what is the number of persons newly employed in pioneer industries set up in the Jurong and Red Hill industrial sites.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, the Member asks about the number of workers newly employed in pioneer industries set up in Jurong and Red Hill industrial sites. There are now 31 pioneer industries in operation in the whole of Singapore, and the total employment provided is 3,186. Of these 31 industries, seven are sited in Jurong with an employment of 495, four in Red Hill with an employment of 142. The total number of persons employed in Jurong and Red Hill both in pioneer and non-pioneer industries comes to 1,135. I may add, Sir, that while the Government

Column: 557

have succeeded in creating 3,186 new jobs in pioneer industries alone, the pro-Communist unions, as a result of political strikes or ill-considered industrial strikes, have caused 1,253 persons to lose their jobs. In addition, another 632 persons lost their jobs in the People's Association and Work Brigade. You will recollect, Mr Speaker, Sir, that when I raised this point two days ago, it was greeted with some scepticism, and I now wish, with your permission, to table detailed lists* of the number of workers who have lost their jobs because of strikes by pro-Communist trade unions in the former strike-happy days.
* Appendix II, cols. 633-36.

    The Chairman: The Assembly was debating an amendment to Head 32 moved by the Member for Paya Lebar. The Minister for Culture had the Floor.

    The Question proposed was,

    "That the total sum to be allocated for Head 32 be reduced by $100.".

    Mr Rajaratnam.

    The Minister for Culture (Mr S. Rajaratnam): Mr Speaker, Sir, yesterday I quoted from the testimony of three gentlemen closely connected with the S.A.T.U. in answer to the Barisan's challenge to show that the Government allegation that the S.A.T.U. is Communist controlled is false or true. We have the evidence from three S.A.T.U. leaders who are far more knowledgeable about S.A.T.U. unions than any of these eight gentlemen here. So, I hope, Sir, after this they will at least be clever enough not

Column: 563

to be provoked by our allegation that they are Communists. The best thing is to keep quiet, which the former gentlemen did, and not try to challenge us to try to prove they are Communists. Again our allegation that S.A.T.U. unions are Communist controlled is not a bogey. It is a fact. Mr James Puthucheary, Mr Woodhull and Mr Lim Shee Ping said so. If that is so and if there is evidence to prove that S.A.T.U. unions are Communist controlled, then it is quite clear that in banning the S.A.T.U. unions, we are not banning ordinary trade unions, but we are banning the Communist controlled outfit out to damage our economy and our country. Probably, Sir, they will keep on denying that they are Communists. And that is a good Communist. Because, Sir, in the Communist book of manual, they are expected and ordered that "if you are a good Communist you must deny that you are a Communist".

    Sir, in a different connotation in a debate in the Legislative Assembly, Vol. 16, 25th January, 1962, col. 707, there was a debate on the trade union issue. I had occasion then, Sir, to quote from Lenin's advice to Communists. He said:

    `It is necessary [for a good Communist] to agree to any and every sacrifice and even, if need be, to resort to all sorts of strategems, manoeuvres, and illegal methods, to evasions and subterfuges...'

"Subterfuges" means lies.

    `in order to penetrate the trade unions, to remain in them, and to carry on Communist work in them at all costs.'.

    So when hon. Members keep on denying that S.A.T.U. trade union Communists are Communist, they are being good Communists. Lenin said so. You must deny that you are a Communist.

    Therefore, Sir, I hope they will be intelligent enough not to deny that the S.A.T.U. unions are Communist controlled.

    Sir, having shown the S.A.T.U. unions are Communist controlled, then it is quite obvious why we have to take action against them and closed them down; not because of their trade union

Column: 564

struggle. In so far as trade unions fight for genuine economic issues, the Government have always supported them. But in so far as trade unions are misused for political and Communist ends, then those leaders and those unions will get into trouble with the law.

    Sir, I have here a book called Lenin on Trade Unions and Revolution. The Communist unions must follow the advice and strategy of the Communist leaders. They make it quite clear, once a Communist gets into a trade union, what he should do with the trade union. That is what the Communists in Singapore are doing. Lenin makes it quite clear and I quote from this book, Lenin on Trade Unions, what a Communist should do in a trade union; not fight for the welfare of the workers.

    1. He must use it for armed violence, violent uprising. And it says. Sir:

    `Armed uprising is the highest method of political struggle for a Communist. For its success a broad development of all sides of the labour movement is necessary.'

    So, Sir, if Communists get into trade unions, they must use trade unions for an armed uprising which is the highest form of political struggle. Therefore, is the Government wrong in taking action against the Communists in trade unions? They are openly committed by their own strategy, by their own theory, by their own ideology, to misusing trade unions for the purposes of Communism.

    2. This is most important and relevant in Singapore. The Communists are advised that there are times when trade unions should be used to make life more miserable for the workers. It is stated so quite clearly. Here, Sir, is another quotation:

    `We cannot and will not in every way promote the improvement of the situation of the workers under existing conditions. We struggle only for such an improvement of the situation of the workers as will increase their ability to lead the class struggle.'.

Which means you only fight for the workers if the fight can increase the prospects for Communists to succeed and for Communism to win.

    `There were times when Lenin declared that the worsening of the condition of the workers under capitalism helps the revolutionary

Column: 565

movement and there were also times when he said the improvement of the workers' lot hurts the revolutionary movement.'

    We can now understand why during the last one year, the S.A.T.U. union leaders deliberately worked for a situation where nearly 1,800 workers were out of job. Why did they deliberately frustrate our industrial development plan? Because they must increase the misery of the workers. These are Lenin's words. And these gentlemen, Woodhull and Puthucheary, have said so. These are controlled by Communists ---

    An hon. Member: Rubbish!

    Mr Rajaratnam: As I have quoted earlier, a good Communist must lie that he is a Communist. He must resort to subterfuges --- [Interruption] And these young men --- [Interruption]

    The Chairman: Order.

    Mr Rajaratnam: Young men taught in the art of falsehood. [Interruption] No, I am quoting Lenin's words. He said that a good Leninist must indulge in subterfuge. And a last parting shot, Sir, If these people are not Communists, I am prepared to give them time over Radio Singapore to come and say why they are not Communists ---

    An hon. Member: Are you a Communist?

    Mr Kow Kee Seng (Paya Lebar): "Are you a Communist?" Please take us to the court if you can.

    The Chairman: Order.

    Mr Chio Cheng Thun(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, when we saw the Minister for Culture stand up, we know he is going to recite his bible. Because apart from shouting Communism, he will not be able to say other things.

    In this House, whenever the Minister for Culture stands up to speak, he

Column: 566

always talks of Communism because he has nothing else to say. He has time and again said he has evidence to show that S.A.T.U. is Communist inspired. Why have the P.A.P. arrested people? They have arrested hundreds of people and they have banned all sorts of organisations. But have they produced these people in court to prove that they are Communists? Since you say that our country is a country of the rule of law, why do they not take them to court and try them? Because there is no evidence. That is the crux of the question. They do not have the evidence. Therefore, they dare not take them to court for an open trial. That shows they cannot solve this question. I am not prepared to rebut the rubbish talk ---

    Mr Rajaratnam: Woodhull, rubbish?

    Mr Chio Cheng Thun(In Mandarin): --- by the Minister for Culture.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, this question involves labour. What I want to point out is that the P.A.P., after their five-year term of office, are now in their second term of office. In words they say they are for the interests of the workers. But are they really for the interests of the workers? The P.A.P. say they want to induce foreign capital to come here. Now what is the basis of attracting foreign capital?

3.15 p.m.

    The basis is to ask the people to starve; they cannot strike. And the inducement to foreign capital would have to be based on the starvation of the workers. This was spoken by the Minister for Finance; it is not rubbish. In 1960 the Minister for Finance said that the P.A.P. did not agree that Singapore should rely only on foreign capital or help the foreign capitalists; we do not depend on them. Is this rubbish? If so, then the Minister for Finance was talking rubbish.

    If they blame the workers for the absence of foreign capitalists, this is not a pro-labour attitude because they ask the workers not to resist the exploitation of foreign capitalists. [Interruption] You are talking rubbish.

    In the past the P.A.P. said that we have a lot of money invested abroad. Why do we not withdraw this money to build more factories in our country for improving the livelihood of our people? They said this was because of the past colonial regime. But when they came to power, what happened? Did they withdraw our capital from abroad in order to build factories here? What are the facts?

    Let me point them out. In 1958-59 our investments abroad amounted to $135 million. This was increased to $320 million in 1961, and it has since been increasing. These figures were given by them, as they had invested our money abroad. On the other hand, they are begging for money, like a son begging from his father. They are begging foreign investors to invest in Singapore. At the same time, they want to suppress the workers, without wanting to improve their living conditions. They have to mortgage our property to the World Bank for loans, payable with interest which comes from the taxpayers. Is this the way to safeguard the interests of the workers and the people of Singapore? The people of Singapore will one day realise whether the P.A.P. do really look after the interests of the workers. Likewise, under its pro-labour policy, the P.A.P. made a lot of promises to the workers. They said that once they formed the government they would unify the trade union movement. But five years after coming to power, has the trade union movement been unified?
